#taxgroup Forest Carnivores species Long-tailed weasel / Mustela frenata
#
# Rank
1
# Nestsite
-99
# Foraging Habitat
-99
# Forage/Prey Availability
-99
# Predator Avoidance
-99
# Refugia/Shelter
-99
# Literature
Distribution
distributed widely across North America from the Canadian provinces of British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan across the remaining southern extremes of Canada, throughout the contintental USA, Mexico, Central America, and into portions of northern South America
General Habitat
variety of habitats, most often prefers open habitats, particularly grasslands and forest edges with patchy resources, but also including dense forests and arid desert
Home or Activity Range
25-250 ac
Specific Habitat Preferences
rocky outcrops for denning, edge habitats
Nestsite Characteristics
dens in rock outcroppings or used dens and burrows of ground squirrels
Foraging Habitat Characteristics
forages at night in rock crevices, brush piles, and animal burrows
Diet
primarily small mammals: mostly voles (meadow vole), mice (deer mice), chipmunks, ground squirrels, rabbits, hares
Predators
bobcat, fox, coyote, eagles, owls, hawks
Shelter Habitats
dens in rock outcroppings or used dens and burrows of ground squirrels
Response to Disturbance
No information available
Sources of Information used in the Model
No information available
General Sources of Background Information
Foresman 2001
Summaries of Specific Studies
No information available
